chapter.title: What is RexxGTK?
chapter.para: RexxGTK is an Object Rexx Class library providing access to the GTK interface available on most Unix/Linux distributions.

It is assumed that you are familiar with the basic GTK functionality and can reference those specific to the system. For more information, refer to the
GNOME Documentation Library.

The RexxGTK package requires that the operating system have the GTK+ libraries available. The minimum version for the Rexx interpreter is ooRexx 4.0. RexxGTK does not work with any other Rexx interpreter/compiler.

section.title: Linux Installation
section.para:
The RexxGTK package is contained in the file rexxgtk.so. This file must be placed in a directory listed in your LD_LIBRARY_PATH or in the system library path. RexxGTK also requires an ooRexx class file (rexxgtk.cls). This file must be placed in a directory listed in your PATH. To get access to the class and methods in the RexxGTK package you must include a ::REQUIRES directive in any Object Rexx script that uses the class: ::REQUIRES directive
. . . ::requires "rexxgtk.cls"

section.title: Windows Installation
section.para:
The RexxGTK package is contained in the file rexxgtk.dll. This file must be placed in a directory listed in your PATH. RexxGTK also requires an ooRexx class file (rexxgtk.cls). This file must be placed in a directory listed in your PATH. To get access to the class and methods in the RexxGTK package you must include a ::REQUIRES directive in any Object Rexx script that uses the class: ::REQUIRES directive

section.title: Classes and Methods
section.para: The RexxGTK package is developed around the class structure of the GTK+ system. For each GTK+ class there is a cooresponding RexxGTK class. Most of the GTK_ functions have a one to one mapping to a cooresponding RexxGTK method with the arguments and return types also matching. However, there are exceptions to the mapping, especially in the more complicated classes where it was determined that a simplified method made more sense in some cases. Also, sometimes it was preferable to return ooRexx builtin objects as opposed to the structures returned by the GTK+ function.

In order to make it easy for a novice to learn the RexxGTK classes and methods the book Foundations of GTK+ Development by Andrew Krause published by Apress® has been used to create a large number of example programs. A user can obtain a copy of this book, which is oriented to C programmers, and examine all the example programs in that book. Each example program has a cooresponding test program contained in the RexxGTK package. Thus a developer can see how to accomplish the same programs in the book using the RexxGTK package. This should get a novice started very quickly.

This document is also organized in much the same way that the
GNOME Documentation Library is organized so locating classes and methods reference manual should be similar.

section.title: Other Notes
section.para: Currently the RexxGTK package is not a complete replication of all GTK+ classes and functions (methods). There are many missing widgets and even more missing functions (methods). It is the intent of the RexxGTK developers to include as many widgets as feasible in the package over time. The same is true for GTK+ functions, but in this case it may take a much longer period of time and it may never be complete.

appendix.title: Sample RexxGTK Programs
appendix.para: The RexxGTK distribution contains a number of example programs. All of these progeams are ported from example programs contained in the book Foundations of GTK+ Development by Andrew Krause published by Apress®.
